question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
If \(P_2\) is a vector space then the axioms must hold true

\(\displaystyle \alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2+\beta_0+\beta_1t+\beta_2t^2= (\alpha_0+\beta_0)+(\alpha_1+\beta_1)t+(\alpha_2+\beta_2)t^2\)

\(\displaystyle c(\alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2)= c\alpha_0+c\alpha_1t+c\alpha_2t^2\)

We can also think of \(P_2\) to be in \(\mathbb{R}^{3}\)

\(\alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2\rightarrow \begin{bmatrix} \alpha_0\\ \alpha_1\\ \alpha_2 \end{bmatrix}\)

such that commutative and associate properties are also satisfied.

To show that B is a basis, we have to show that it spans \(P_2\) and are linearly independent

If we think of \(P_2\) to be in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) then we can immediately identify the basis for \(\mathbb{R}^3\)

Basis of \(\mathbb{R}^3: \left\{\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \right\}\)

We can use this result and build the basis of \(P_2\) such that

\(B=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}+ t\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}+ t^2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ t\\ t^2 \end{bmatrix}\).

Therefore

\(f(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -3 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ t\\ t^2 \end{bmatrix} = 1 -3t + 2t^2\)
sols_latex:
If $P_2$ is a vector space then the axioms must hold true

$\displaystyle \alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2+\beta_0+\beta_1t+\beta_2t^2= (\alpha_0+\beta_0)+(\alpha_1+\beta_1)t+(\alpha_2+\beta_2)t^2$

$\displaystyle c(\alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2)= c\alpha_0+c\alpha_1t+c\alpha_2t^2$

We can also think of $P_2$ to be in $\mathbb{R}^{3}$

$\alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2\rightarrow \begin{bmatrix}
\alpha_0\\
\alpha_1\\
\alpha_2
\end{bmatrix}$

such that commutative and associate properties are also satisfied.

To show that B is a basis, we have to show that it spans $P_2$ and are
linearly independent

If we think of $P_2$ to be in $\mathbb{R}^3$ then we can immediately
identify the basis for $\mathbb{R}^3$

Basis of $\mathbb{R}^3: \left\{\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix},
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix},
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
\right\}$

We can use this result and build the basis of $P_2$ such that

$B=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}+
t\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}+
t^2\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
t\\
t^2
\end{bmatrix}$.

Therefore

$f(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -3 & 2
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
1\\
t\\
t^2
\end{bmatrix} = 1 -3t + 2t^2$

If <math>P_2</math> is a vector space then the axioms must hold true

<math> \displaystyle \alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2+\beta_0+\beta_1t+\beta_2t^2= (\alpha_0+\beta_0)+(\alpha_1+\beta_1)t+(\alpha_2+\beta_2)t^2</math>

<math> \displaystyle c(\alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2)= c\alpha_0+c\alpha_1t+c\alpha_2t^2</math>

We can also think of <math>P_2</math> to be in <math>\mathbb{R}^{3}</math>

<math>\alpha_0+\alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2\rightarrow \begin{bmatrix}
\alpha_0\\
\alpha_1\\
\alpha_2
\end{bmatrix}</math>

such that commutative and associate properties are also satisfied.

To show that B is a basis, we have to show that it spans <math>P_2</math> and are linearly independent

If we think of <math>P_2</math> to be in <math>\mathbb{R}^3</math> then we can immediately identify the basis for <math>\mathbb{R}^3</math>

Basis of <math>\mathbb{R}^3: \left\{\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix},
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix},
\begin{bmatrix}

0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
\right\}</math>

We can use this result and build the basis of <math>P_2</math> such that

<math>B=\begin{bmatrix}

0
\end{bmatrix}+
t\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}+
t^2\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
t\\
t^2
\end{bmatrix}</math>.

Therefore

<math>f(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -3 & 2
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
1\\
t\\
t^2
\end{bmatrix} = 1 -3t + 2t^2</math>
statement_html:
Let \(P_2=\{ \alpha_0+ \alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2: \alpha_j \in \mathbb{R} (j=0,1,2) \}\) be the set of all polynomials of degree at most 2.

Show that \(\displaystyle P_2\) is a vector space and show that \(\displaystyle B=\{1,t,t^2 \}\) form a basis of \(\displaystyle P_2\). Express the function \(\displaystyle f(t)=1-3t+2t^2 \in P_2\) in a vector form using B as the basis.
statement_latex:
Let
$P_2=\{ \alpha_0+ \alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2: \alpha_j \in \mathbb{R} (j=0,1,2) \}$
be the set of all polynomials of degree at most 2.

Show that $\displaystyle P_2$ is a vector space and show that
$\displaystyle B=\{1,t,t^2 \}$ form a basis of $\displaystyle P_2$.
Express the function $\displaystyle f(t)=1-3t+2t^2 \in P_2$ in a vector
form using \emph{B} as the basis.
statement_raw:
Let <math>P_2=\{ \alpha_0+ \alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2: \alpha_j \in \mathbb{R} (j=0,1,2) \}</math> be the set of all polynomials of degree at most 2.

Show that <math>\displaystyle P_2</math> is a vector space and show that <math>\displaystyle B=\{1,t,t^2 \}</math> form a basis of <math>\displaystyle P_2</math>. Express the function <math>\displaystyle f(t)=1-3t+2t^2 \in P_2</math> in a vector form using ''B'' as the basis.
